content.question: A company claims it audits its employees’ transactions based on their job level. For entry-level positions, the company claims that 50 percent get a basic audit, 30 percent get an enhanced audit, and 20 percent get a complete audit. The company tests this hypothesis using a random sample and finds <math alttext="chi square equals 0.771" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>0.771</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with a corresponding <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value of 0.68. Assuming conditions for inference were met, which of the following is the correct interpretation of the <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>–value?

choices.label: There is a 68 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of at least 0.771.
There is a 68 percent chance that the company’s claim is correct.
If the null hypothesis were true, there would be a 68 percent chance that the company’s claim is correct.
If the null hypothesis were true, there would be a 68 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of 0.771.
If the null hypothesis were true, there would be a 68 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of at least 0.771.

content.answer: If the null hypothesis were true, there would be a 68 percent chance of obtaining a chi-square value of at least 0.771.
